participants.participant: José Sáinz Armada, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good morning. We're going to begin the presentation of results for the first quarter of 2010. The meeting will last approximately an hour and a half. In other words, we will have finished by 11. So the Chairman of IBERDROLA, Mr. Sánchez Galán, has the floor.

Good morning, everyone. I'd like to start by thanking you for attending the meeting, both of you that are here and those that are connected via phone or the website. We will have the usual structure. First of all, I'll comment on the main aspects of the results for the first quarter of 2010. Then José Sáinz Armada will analyze those results and the financial position, and I will end with some brief conclusions before moving on to the questions.

In these first 3 months of the year, IBERDROLA has obtained a gross operating profit of €2,178 million with a growth of 11.6% and a net profit of €922 million. This is an increase of 16.2%. These results come from the investments made in recent years which have made IBERDROLA a diversified group, a leader in generation with clean energy and a world reference in efficiency. And this since our business portfolio and geography enables us to stay on the path of sustainable growth and focus on the various areas, depending on the circumstances.

The regulated and renewable activities have benefited from an increase of 15% in Group production as a result of the hydroelectric and wind power technologies. And this once again shows the wise decision of putting our stakes on emission-free technologies. As I announced at the recent presentation of the financial forecast for 2010-2012, efficiency is going to continue to be the sign of identity for the Group. The effects of the measures implemented can already be seen in the first quarter where all Group businesses have shown improvements.

Regarding the Group balance sheet structure, it is very clear that IBERDROLA is committed to a solid financial position. Leverage is 45.6% with an improvement of close to 7 percentage points since March 2009 and the main financial ratios have also been significantly strengthened. Thanks to this, the Standard & Poor's rating has recently reaffirmed an A rating for IBERDROLA.

Finally, I would like to highlight the approval of the Royal Decree on the securitization of the tariff deficit. This represents a significant move forward in the collection of the amounts due to the companies. So IBERDROLA starts the 3 year period 2010-2012 with results that based on the strategic basis announced some months ago have already exceeded the forecast growth rate for the period.

Group production in the first 3 months of 2010 amounted to 42,000 gigawatt hours with a growth of 15.4% compared to the same period last year. This has been possible thanks to the increase in 100% emission-free generation, the contribution of which has increased by more than 10 points up to 50% of the total, driven, as I said, by the hydraulic and wind power technologies. If we add gas combined cycle generation, the most efficient technology in thermal generation, over 90% of the Group's total production comes from sources that respect the environment.

Regarding production in Spain, it has benefited from the growth in demand, close to 5% in the quarter, as well as from the increase in hydraulic and wind power production. All this has enabled us to obtain an increase of 28% in energy produced, up to 21,700 gigawatt hours. Also, and as we have been reporting over the last quarters, the full liberalization of the market has opened new opportunities in the generation market. In this sense, over 90% of the energy produced by IBERDROLA between January and March has been sold on markets that are different to the daily market, mainly term markets or end customer markets. This reduces price volatility.

The high hydro levels in the quarter has meant we have sold a larger amount of hydroelectric energy to the pool, slightly over 2 terawatt hours. With this major increase in hydraulic production which has multiplied by 2.5, our reserves are currently at over 80% of the capacity, with a 9,000 gigawatt hours. This represents an increase of 45% over the figures recorded in March 2009.

Regarding cost developments, in the first quarter of the year, the Group has achieved an increase of 8% in operating efficiency. The increase of 9.2% in gross margin has been obtained with a very moderate development in net operating costs which have grown less than 1 percentage point. Personnel costs have significantly contributed to this with a drop of 0.5% in gross terms and they're on the same level in net terms. The increase in activity together with efficiency improvements means that the Group's gross operating profits have grown by 11.6% to €2,178 million.

The breakdown by business areas is very similar to our objective for 2012, with the exception of the contribution of the renewable business, which obviously will increase in the coming years with the planned investments. The contribution of the energy business in Spain is 33% and has behaved solidly in the quarter. Scottish Power contributes 24%, RENOVABLES 20% and businesses in Latin America and IBERDROLA USA each contribute approximately 10%. By activities, these results show the benefits of the diversified business low-risk model at IBERDROLA.

In the last 2 years, the Group has obtained similar EBITDA growth, so close to 10%. But the businesses that have driven this growth have alternated, showing that the combination of IBERDROLA's activities makes it possible to grow in very different environments.

In the first quarter of 2010, we can highlight the positive performance of IBERDROLA RENOVABLES, with a growth of 30% in EBITDA and especially in liberalized businesses in Spain. In regulated businesses, the growth registered by Brazil and the UK has offset the drop in business in the U.S., mainly affected by the exchange rate.

Regarding the most outstanding events in the various businesses starting with the regulated businesses in Spain, we must first highlight the approval of the Royal Decree to develop the securitization of the tariff deficit. As announced recently on Investors' Day, this norm concludes the regulatory process for securitization and now it only needs to be registered at the CNMV. On the other hand, I would like to highlight the efficiency measures implemented in the regulated business in Spain, the personnel cost of which has dropped by 7%.

Regarding activities regulated in the UK, on April 1, the new remuneration for distribution for the next 5 years came into operation. Scottish Power is already implementing different saving initiatives which according to our estimates will make it possible to obtain profitability over assets of more than 100 base points over the regulatory profitability.

In the U.S., the negotiation for the new remuneration of activities for electricity and gas in New York continue and the expectation is that the new tariffs will come into effect at the end of the summer. On the other hand, the company is already working on the implementation on operational improvements. And a number of plans have recently been announced to adapt the workforce, which has already allowed a reduction of 6% to be carried out in comparison to the figures 12 months ago.

Finally, I would like to highlight the good performance of regulated businesses in Latin America, particularly in Brazil, where demand is growing at levels close to 9% in our business areas, with the consequential effect on results. Brazil will continue to be a strategic country for IBERDROLA, not only in the distribution area, but also in the area of generation. And as you all know, we have an important portfolio of hydraulic projects.

Regarding liberalized activities, we can highlight the very good performance of the business in Spain as a result of the flexibility of the generation portfolio as well of the use of the opportunities offered by liberalization. In this sense, we have sold over 62 terawatt hours on the Spanish market, a figure that represents more than 90% of our budgeted production at the beginning of the year.

On the other hand, we are carrying out a number of measures to manage our long-term gas contract portfolio in order to ensure supplies with the lowest risk for the Group. We have already placed all the gas for the year 2010 and we have recently signed a contract to supply 1 bcm of gas per year during a period that could be as much as 15 years, starting in 2011.

Regarding the United Kingdom, the consortium led by Scottish Power recently became one of the two finalists in the contest to build a plant for the capture and sequestration of CO2. During the next months we'll carry out an engineering study financed partially by the British government to specify the technical and economic conditions for this project. I would also like to highlight that the main parties of the British election, show in their programs a clearer support for this technology through measures such as establishing a tax to finance up to 4 projects.

On the other hand, Scottish Power recently announced a drop of 8% in gas prices as of April 1. This initiative together with others will enable us to preserve a competitive position in the commercial business in the United Kingdom. So far this year, Scottish Power has been capable of maintaining its number of customers with a variation of less than 0.4%.

Regarding IBERDROLA RENOVABLES, the company recorded in the quarter an increase of around 25% both in operating power and in energy produced. The company continues to show its capacity to bring together its expansion process with a significant cost reduction, which has obtained a gain in efficiency of 6%. And at the same time RENOVABLES will continue to work in the future both in the short, medium and long-term.

In the recent months, we have signed energy sales contracts in the U.S. Thanks to this we have increased the proportion of energy subject to a fixed price and covers 93% of our total production. With our sights on the next few years, the company has also started up its ocean wind power division with headquarters in Glasgow to ensure an advance in the various projects in the UK and the rest of Europe.

And now I would like to briefly cover the regulatory situation for the renewable energy sector in Spain. As many of you know, and as you heard yesterday, as a result of the presentation of the results for RENOVABLES, in recent years there has been a very different development for the various renewable technologies in Spain. In 2009, installed wind power in Spain was 90% of the objective set for 2010, about 20,000 megawatts. While in the case of photovoltaic power, installed power was more than 3,400 megawatts. That is seven times more than the objective set for 2010.

This situation is a result of the existing remuneration for each technology. Wind power in Spain has a tariff of around €77 per megawatt hour, which is much lower than that in the rest of European countries, whose average remuneration is around €102 per megawatt. However, in the case of photovoltaic energy, our country which has high load factors, much higher than in Germany, for example, has a tariff of €466 per megawatt hour for around 3,500 megawatts, according to Decree 661, much higher than countries in our area. As a result, there's a major difference between the contribution of energy and the contribution to production costs of the various technologies.

In 2009, wind power produced 14% of the total energy generated in Spain, representing 16% of the total production cost, while solar energies contributed only 2% of the energy and also cost 16% of the cost of supply. On the other hand, cogeneration, biomass and other technologies produced 12%, representing a cost of 18%. The special regime, that is all the technologies under some kind of premium, produced 28% of the energy and represented 50% of the total cost.

With the rate of the new renewable power estimated in the pre-register, this situation will become more intense in the future and will have a major impact on the sustainability of the system. In 2013, it is expected that wind power will produce 19% of the energy, representing 18% of the cost, while photovoltaic energy will only provide 3% of the energy and will represent 15% of the cost. On the other hand, and this is very important, the major thermosolar expansion anticipated in coming years will mean that this technology will represent 8% of the production costs and will only contribute 1.8% of the energy to the system. The rest of the technologies, cogeneration, biomass and other technologies, will represent around 13% of the production and also 13% of the cost.

In conclusion, it can be said that while the development of wind energy has been sustainable, and according to the objective set in the Renewable Energy Plan 2005-2010, solar technologies have grown exponentially in recent years and have exceeded the objectives. In this way, the greater use of less mature renewables, that is that have a great potential for improvement in the future, have significantly increased the cost of the electrical supply since the investment costs are much higher.

The annual economic impact – and these figures are important – for each 1,000 megawatts of these technologies, thermosolar energy increases €900 million. Photovoltaic increases the cost by 600 million and wind power represents an increase of only €70 million. These are the premiums for these technologies with the current remuneration. If we do not want to substantially increase the price of electricity, it is necessary to defer the growth of thermosolar and photovoltaic energy, which contribute little energy and represent a very high cost.

Moving on to analyze the balance sheet, the situation of the company in March reflects the measures implemented during recent quarters in order to control investments and optimize the debt structure. Leverage is 45.6%, almost 7 points below about 12 months ago. And the main financial ratios have experienced a significant improvement and are comfortably in levels that correspond to a type A credit rating. As a result of all this, Standard & Poor's have recently reaffirmed, as I said earlier, the A rating for IBERDROLA debt at this time.

The solid operational development of the company and the improvement in its financial position has represented an increase of 16.2% in net profits, €922 million, and 17.1% in operating cash flow, which has come close to €1,500 million in just 3 months.
And now I'll hand the floor over to José Sáinz Armada, so that he can give us more details on all the results.

Thank you very much, President. Good morning, and now what I would like to do is review the most relevant aspects of the accounts of the first quarter and the operating evolution by businesses. And I would like to finish with an analysis of the funding situation of the Group.

The company initiated the year, as the President pointed out, with strong growth in the main lines of the results account, which shows the strength of our diversified business model in different environments. So the gross margin has grown 9.2%, EBITDA 11.8%, and recurrent net profits have grown 10.6%. So the impact by the rate of exchange is very low in the consolidated statement of this quarter, about 5 million, because the devaluation of the dollar has been compensated by the appreciation of the pound and the real in Brazil.

The gross margin has grown 9.2% and now stands at €3,224 million, thanks mainly to the growth of the national energy business which has grown 14%, renewables 28%, and because Brazil has behaved very well, with growth of 44%. The basic margin that registers the net effect of the emission rights in the accounts has grown 8.4%, which is somewhat less than the gross margin, and now stands at €3,292 million because of the lower price and consumption of CO2 in 2010 versus 2009.

The sales figure grows 0.6% up to €7,687 million with higher volumes in Spain compensated by lower price in the ordinary regime and by lower remuneration and distribution, and by strong growth in renewables and Latin America. As far as the procurement of the Group is concerned, they have dropped 3.8% and now stand at €4,363 million, especially on renewables, Scottish Power, IBERDROLA USA and that compensate the growths of the other businesses.

Net operating expenses have grown only 0.7% and now stand at €893 million as a consequence of the efficiency plan that is being carried out by the Group, as the President pointed out. And the net personnel expenses are stable at about €430 million and the net external services have only grown 1.2% and now stand at €463 million. As regards the levies, there has been an increase of 11% up to €221 million. And this also includes the inclusion of the payment of the ENRESA rates and the social bond and other rates in the United States. And this compensates the claw back of CO2 compared to the first quarter of 2009.

So as a consequence of this, the EBITDA of the Group has grown 11.6% and has reached €2,178 million, so therefore, shows how strong the business model is. And the different operating environments of 2010 means that in this quarter the businesses are boosting the operating growth of the Group are the deregulated business that has grown 17%, renewables, that's grown 30%, whereas the regulated business has grown 2%.

Now I would like to give you some details regarding the evolution of EBITDA in each of the Group's businesses but starting off with the deregulated business in Spain that includes generation, commercial and non-regulated gas. IBERDROLA has increased its ordinary regime output by 27% and it's improved its evolution in the system. That has dropped 3%. And this positive trend can be explained by the growth in demand in Spain, that is 4.7% more, and because there's been a sharp increase in the hydraulic production of IBERDROLA, 158% more than last year.

In addition to that, our nuclear output has grown 5.4% whereas the thermal technologies have dropped from 30% in the case of combined cycles and coal plus fuel 64%. So that means that the production, the percentage of production, at a zero variable cost has gone from 67% in the first quarter in 2009 to 83% in the first quarter of 2010. We've achieved an average sale price of €55.6 per megawatt hour with an output that is much higher than what we expected.

The average unit cost of fuel at IBERDROLA has only been €10 per megawatt hour and this average fuel cost cannot be replicated by our competitors because of our competitive low-cost production mix. It has to be pointed out that we are selling – we sold 62 terawatts hour in 2010 at a price above €50 per megawatt hour, which represents more than 90% of the output that was estimated for this year.

The EBITDA of the deregulated business in Spain has grown 41% and now stands at €492 million because there's been an improvement in the basic margin. That's grown 29% and now reaches €765 million, which is due, as I said before, to the greater volumes and to the greater percentage of technologies that are low-cost in the mix. And this growth to the basic margin is clearly higher than that of operating costs that have grown 8%, in spite of the increase of the commercial activities and because the last resorted tariff has been transferred to the deregulated business. Taxes have gone up 20% and now stand at €93 million because the reduction of CO2 compensates this item in relation to the social bond and the ENRESA rate.

The EBITDA of the regulated business in Spain has grown 1.7% and now stands at € 254 million. This has managed to counteract the 7.5% slump that was recorded at the level of the gross margin, thanks to an 18% reduction in the net operating expenses because the area is improving its efficiency, and we are transferring costs to the deregulated business. And this 7.5% reduction in the gross business margin is a consequence of the temporary reduction in the remuneration of the business, are subsequent to the new ministerial order of December the 31. And this reduction has been 6.5% vis-à-vis Q1 of 2009 and 2.8% if we were to compare it with the average figure of 2009 after the adjustment of €61 million in the fourth quarter of 2009. So we're talking about temporary remunerations but we have to wait for the definitive remuneration that is based on the reference model.

EBITDA grew 30% and now stands at €441 million. That is the RENOVABLES EBITDA, thanks to the strong increase in production which was 26%, which has to do with the greater operating capacity. That's grown 22.1% and we now have a figure of 10,789 megawatts installed. And we also have had a slight increase in prices and the average price is €73.53 per megawatt hour because of the hedging agreement in Spain as well as because of the PPA signed in the United States. And then the gross margin of the gas business has grown 45% and nearly provides €60 million to the accounts.

Net operating expenses have grown less than the gross margin, 18.6%, which is less than the increase in operating capability. And as the President had pointed out, the OpEx per operating megawatt has improved by 6%.

The EBITDA of Scottish Power in local currency dropped 2.7% and now stands at £465 million after 2.1 slump that has affected the base figure gross margin. Whilst net operating expenses still continue with the containment after being reduced at 0.5% in euros, the EBITDA have reduced its drop to 0.5% and now stands at €527 million after having positive impact because of the rate of exchange, 10 million.

And as regards wholesale and retail, they are drops that have been partially compensated by a much better development in networks. Wholesale and retail provide €324 million for the EBITDA with a net 7% drop, basically due to the retail business where there are less volumes, that is, minus 1.7%, and less unit margins, about 4%, because of the reduction in prices in 2009.

Networks has contributed €184 million and that means that it's an 8.5% growth. And this has to do with the 7.3 growth of the gross margin where there has been more revenue linked to the new investments made both in transmission and distribution with a very important part for the connection of new renewables. And these effects are partially compensated by lower volume of distributed power, which is under 1%.

The outcomes of IBERDROLA USA in dollars in U.S. GAAP are the following. EBITDA has dropped 3.1% and now stands at $279 million. However, the gross margin shows a growth rate of 0.7%, thanks to the increase in prices, especially in the gas business that compensates the slight decline in demand in this business that was 0.8%, as well as a lower contribution of the electrical business after the slump in demand, which was about 2%. There has been an improvement in net operating expenses, 3%, after a 6% reduction in the personnel figure.

Then improvements in the net operating expenses will be higher in the next quarters. The increase in levies, which is 28%, that was applied in April 2009, explains the progression of the EBITDA in dollars and in U.S. GAAP.

As regards the results of the business in euros and under IFRS, IBERDROLA has made a contribution of €202 million for the EBITDA which is an 11.3 slump, which can be explained fundamentally by the effect produced by the devaluation of the dollar, which is about 7%, which is nearly $15 million, and the increase in levies of 12%. And in this quarter, the adjustments because of the application of the U.S. GAAP to IFRS have been minimal.

The EBITDA of Latin America has a strong growth rate, up to 20% up to €226 million and has maintained a progression that has been seen in terms of the gross margin because there has been an improvement in the Brazil results.

Brazil and Mexico have a completely different kind of behavior. Brazil contributes €135 million to the EBITDA. That means that it's a 47% growth including €22 million that have to do with the revaluation of the real. In local currency, the business has grown 18%, thanks to the increase in demand, that was 8.5%, as well as to an improvement of the margins in our distributors in the region that have registered the positive effect of the adjustments made represents inflation.

Mexico contributes 91 million to EBITDA, which is a 5% drop. The effects caused by the rate of exchange, which is 7.3%, has subtracted €7 million. So that means that the behavior of EBITDA in local currency presents a positive trend, 2.1%, linked to an improvement in margins and linked to the availability of power stations. And EBITDA of non-energy products and engineering has 16% slump, totaling €56 million. Engineering or ingeniería is the main contributor as regards the gross margin with 48% of the total. And there's been 10% reduction in net operating expenses which tries to soften the drop in gross margin.

The EBITDA of the Group grew 7.8% and now stands at €1,536 million, which is somewhat below the growth we've registered at the level of EBITDA after a 22% increase in the chapter on amortizations and provisions, with a total of 642 million. Amortizations are 604 million after growing 90 million due to the increase in renewables with higher installed power, and in Scottish Power with the appreciation of the pound and more assets under exploitation in the networks area. But environmental investments in Spain have increased this item in the Spanish liberalized or the regulated business. Provisions have been increased 25 million and now stand at 38 in a quarter that was unfavorable compared to 2009, in which there was some reversals.

So the net financial result shows an 8.8 reduction and it now stands at €297 million. Net expenses in relation to interest related to the debt have dropped 13% and now stand at €325 million as a result of the decline in the average costs which is now 4.2 instead of 4.9, in spite of a slight increase in the average balance of the net debt and the lower rate of remuneration of deficit and certain hedging actions because of the revaluation of the dollar and the real have had a slight negative impact in terms of financial expenses. However, the total net financial result has achieved, as I said before, a reduction of 8.8%.

Profit before taxes has grown 14.5% and now reaches €1,310 million at a rate that is somewhat higher than that of the EBITDA based on an 11.6% increase registered in recurrent profits. And the credit control of financial expenses and the increase of 36 million in the results of non-working assets, which includes divestiture on behalf of EDP more than compensate the reductions that have occurred.

And the improvement in operating results have increased the Group's operating cash flow 17.1%, which nearly has reached €1.5 million in the quarter. And the net profit has grown 16.2% and now stand at €922 million. And the tax rate is 26.5% in the first quarter which is somewhat lower than what we had last year with 28%.

I would like to start off with the presentation that has to do with the financial chapter with an updating of the tariff deficit that the President pointed out. And on April the 21 of 2010 Royal Decree 437/2010 was published that develops the regulation of the securitization process of the deficit of electrical system. And the Royal Decree confirms the key issues that were represented at the Investors' Day.

The tariff deficit that's on the balance sheet of the company will be transferred to the fund at its nominal value. And the Royal Decree says that the maximum figures recognized will be up to 10 billion including past deficits until 2008 and 3.5 billion for 2009. For 2010 and 2012 each year, this will be determined without being able to exceed the maximum figure established in Royal Decree 6/2009.

And the figures established are 3 billion for 2010, 2 billion for 2011 and 1 billion for 2012, and the tariff deficit will disappear as from that moment onwards. And the tariff deficits generated between 2010 and 2012 will be recognized ex-ante and can be awarded to the securitization fund of the system. And the fund has 12 months to purchase rights from the moment that the electrical utilities wish to surrender them.

So subsequent to the Royal Decree, the regulatory process, as the President has pointed out, has finished. And now it is at the Securities and Exchange Commission where this has to be duly registered, and apparently this has advanced.

And on March 2010, the tariff deficit has increased €166 million relative to the figure we had on the balance sheet on the closing date of 2009, and now stands at €3,784 million. And this increase of 166 million is the net result of an increase in the deficit of 218 million in the quarter and a collection of 52 million from the tariff. And the funds at the end of the first quarter of 2010 account for €30,184 million, that is, €4 billion more than one year ago, whereas net debt without considering the tariff deficit stands at €25,310 million, which is more than 3 billion less than in the first quarter of 2009.

And all of this means that we've achieved a substantial improvement in the leverage that has gone down from 52.5% one year ago to – it's nearly 700 basis points less. But if we include the tariff deficit, we're talking about a debt of €29,094 million, that is, €2.1 billion less in debt compared to last year, and leverage would be increased to 49.1%.

The strict control of debt and the growth achieved as regards the generation of operating cash flow has allowed the company to show that all the financial ratios on the closing date of Q1 have grown a lot vis-à-vis the ratios of the same period of the previous year. With the exclusion of the tariff deficit, the FFO relative to the net debt stands at 20.5% versus 16% last year. The FFO relative to interest, it's 5 times instead of 4.4 times. And the return cash flow relative to the net debt stands at 14%, which is nearly 3.4% above the figure of 11.6 reported for last year. The improvements in the financial ratios shown in this quarter will be consolidated throughout the year, which will allow us to achieve the objectives that have been set for 2010.

As regards the breakdown of debt, based on funding sources, we still maintain a suitable diversification. We have increased the weight of the debt financed in capital markets which now stands at 72%, 64% in bonds and 8% in IOUs.

And as regards the structure of the debt by currencies, we have to say that the coverage policy or the hedging policy tries to reduce the risk in terms of rates of exchange. At the same time, it also tries to adjust the percentage of debt per currency to minimize the volatility of the leverage and of the solvency ratios. And in this regard, the debt in euros accounts for 50% of the total whereas the debt in pounds and dollars stands at 26 and 21% respectively.

As regards the structure of the debt by interest rate, we maintain a very cautious structure, with 40% of the debt with a variable rate and 52% with a fixed rate. And we also have a wonderful liquidity position, because right now we have nearly €7.8 billion in liquidity and available credit lines and special – 4,900 are as from 2012. And we have to point out that we are covering the needs for more than 15 months of operation of the Group without having to resort to the market. And the maturity time schedule, and for loans as you can see here, offers comfortable system which is also stable. The average life of the debt is 6 years, which is in line with the objectives set by the margin.

I would like to close this presentation by showing you the tentative time schedule of the upcoming scrip dividend, the new remuneration system that was approved by the General Shareholder Assembly that will allow people to receive shares released by the company or to pay for them. And on May the 14, we'll send to the Securities and Exchange Commission information on the scrip dividend and on the enlargement of capital released. And this slide shows the temporary time schedule. And as you can see, the date of payment for those shareholders that decide to sell their shares to IBERDROLA will be July 1 and on July the 2 these new shares will be listed on the stock exchange.
And now, the President will close this presentation of results.

Thank you very much, Pepe. I think that results we are presenting show the capacity of the IBERDROLA business portfolio to obtain growth in any macroeconomic and business scenario. The investments made in recent years have enabled us to increase our presence in markets such as the U.S. or British market, maintaining our stakes in Mexico and Brazil and reducing the weight of the traditional business in Spain, which currently represents only one-third of the Group's gross operating profits. The contribution to the results of the regulated and renewable businesses stays around 60%, therefore, providing a high predictability to the accounts.

This solid position has enabled us to obtain in this first quarter of 2010 an increase in results of 11.6% on an operating level and 16% on a level of net profits. In the first 3 months of the year, the Group also increased its production by 15.4%, thanks to the contribution of technologies with a reduced variable cost and emission-free, such as hydraulic and wind power technologies.

All the countries in which IBERDROLA is present have contributed to this increase with the exception of the UK, which has been affected by a more timid development in demand and the shutdown of the coal power station at Longannet, which is again operational. The increase of 28% in production in Spain is linked to the good status of the wind power business in the U.S. country where generated energy has increased by 23%, and activities in Latin America where energy production has increased by 7%. In other countries, renewables has increased its production by over 40%.

One of the signs of identity of the Group is the constant search for improvements in efficiency. And one of the results we can present today are clearly the first effects of the saving measures implemented in the various businesses. Cost containment, which has enabled costs to grow less than 1% in homogeneous terms, have enabled an overall efficiency improvement of 8%.

But I want to highlight the following aspects. In Spain, the Group is carrying out the transition to a fully liberalized market efficiency, which has provoked an increase in costs of less than 2%. In the UK, Scottish Power has cut down costs by an additional 1% in pounds. In the U.S., the workforce has been optimized with a 6% reduction. And IBERDROLA RENOVABLES, the costs per installed megawatt, have fallen by 6%, showing once again the capability of the company to carry out its expansion process in an efficient manner.

The third key point in the results we've presented today is that the improvement of our situation. Over the last 12 months, the balance sheet of the company has been strengthened very significantly as the CFO has said, with an increase of over 4 billion in equity and a drop of 3 billion in debt. Thanks to this, leverage is 45.6% with an improvement of close to 7 points, which is significant related to last year. The financial ratios of the Group have also experienced a major strengthening with the support of cash flow generation which has increased by 17% in the period, and therefore, Standard & Poor's has recently reaffirmed our A rating.

Regarding prospects of the Group for the rest of the year, I would like to reaffirm the plans announced 2 months ago, when the results for 2009 were presented. We expect the regulated businesses to show a neutral to positive trend both in Spain and Latin America, and to improve in the UK and United States as a result of the regulatory revisions. IBERDROLA RENOVABLES will maintain the path of growth, thanks to the increase in capacity and price stabilization, mainly thanks to tariffs or PPAs.

In liberalized businesses, we continue to expect a positive development in Spain, thanks on the one hand to the recovery in demand and the historic level of hydraulic reserves, 9,000 gigawatt hours, 45% more than last year. In the UK, the situation will be more complex, particularly because of the pressures on generation margins and retail prices. As I said, we will maintain our focus on operating efficiency in all businesses, and especially in the United States where the measures launched from the beginning of the year are already being fruitful.
